Description: Glazed composition scaraboid; back in form of head of Black African, cut out with blade, hair marked with diaper pattern, straight line across forehead, facial features now lost except large eyes and ears; at side, single line; underside decorated with incised stylised representation of two crocodiles head to tail; pierced through head, just below hairline; glaze gone; core yellow; surface quite eroded.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie (probably)
Curator's comments: The faience object was analysed by proton induced X-ray emission spectrometry (PIXE) under a 3 MeV energy proton beam for characterisation of the elemental chemical composition (major, minor and trace elements), in March 2014, by the Centre de Recherche et de Restauration des Musées de France (C2RMF). Gorton assigned this scaraboid to her type XXXVI, regrouping a variety of motifs and shapes (Gorton 1996, type XXXVI, subtype 32-34, see especially 35 for this specimen). It was produced at Naukratis itself (on the various productions of the "Scarab Factory", see Webb forthcoming). A pair of crocodiles head to tail is a popular motif on scarabs and scaraboids (see various examples in Hornung and Staehelin 1976, 347-348, 381-382, 392, pl. 89, pl. 111, no. 797-799, B51and D21). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Hornung, E., Staehelin, E. 1976. Skarabäen und andere Siegelamulette aus Basler Sammlungen, Ägyptische Denkmäler in der Schweiz I. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 11)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p.130, Type XXXVI, no. 35)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.070) (phase 3)
